<h1>Notes on Web3</h1>
<figure>
<picture style="aspect-ratio: 800 / 446;">
<source srcset="/img/megara-dance.webp" type="image/webp"/>

">Kvindedansen i Megara, 1888-1889, Niels Skovgaard</a></figcaption>
</figure>
<p>It‚Äôs pos­si­ble you have, in recent months, seen peo­ple writ­ing with excite­ment (or curiosity, or consternation) about ‚ÄúWeb3‚Äù. The term imag­ines the tran­si­tion of many inter­net services to a model built around cryp­to­graphic tokens, such that own­er­ship and/or con­trol of those ser­vices might be divided between their token-holders, a group that might include their users. The tokens would also have exchange value, so, as a user, you could always: cash out ü§ë</p>
<p>Ethereum is the locus of most of this <span class="nobr">work — </span><wbr>hey, who named that client library <code>web3.js</code>, <span class="nobr">anyway? — </span><wbr>so it‚Äôs not unrea­son­able to read ‚ÄúWeb3‚Äù as ‚ÄúEthereum-powered inter­net‚Äù.</p>
<p class="alert audience non-subscriber-only">This message was emailed to lab newsletter subscribers. The assumed audience is subscribers who know roughly what Web3 is supposed to be, but aren‚Äôt sure what to think about it. (<a href="/colophon#assumed-audiences">Here‚Äôs more about assumed audiences.</a>)</p>
<p>If you are already con­vinced that Web3 is the appro­pri­ate next step for the world‚Äôs inter­net­worked com­puter systems: this post is not for you. Go forth!</p>
<p>Instead, this is for peo­ple still sort of … cautiously curi­ous?</p>
<p>Cards on the table: I am not merely a skeptic, but a full-fledged enemy of Web3. I hope my ani­mos­ity can‚Äôt be instantly dismissed: ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a hater; he‚Äôs old; he doesn‚Äôt under­stand the technology.‚Äù I am, in fact, <span class="nobr">old — </span><wbr><span class="nobr">41! — </span><wbr>but, as mit­i­gat­ing evidence: I write sci­ence fic­tion; am deeply curi­ous about the future(s) of the inter­net; and even pro­duced a well-received <a href="https://text.bargains/amulet/">NFT project</a>.</p>
<p>I don‚Äôt intend any great rhetor­i­cal effect with the notes below; I just want to offer them as mea­ger coun­ter­weight to the grow­ing hype. I think Web3 speaks strongly to peo­ple whose thoughts bend often toward those inter­net futures … so, in a sense, I‚Äôm post­ing this for other ver­sions of myself. Hello!</p>
<p>Here are my notes on Web3:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>It‚Äôs for kids. I mean that in a good way! I think Web3 has res­onated pow­er­fully with young peo­ple because it feels like some­thing gen­uinely new, and it feels like it can be theirs. Who could argue with those feelings? Not me.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>I think Web3 is pro­pelled by exhaus­tion as much as by excite­ment. This isn‚Äôt appar­ent on the surface, but I believe it‚Äôs there, lurk­ing just below. If you are 22¬†years old, Twit­ter has been around for about as long as you‚Äôve known how to read. YouTube is fixed as firmly as the stars. I honestly don‚Äôt know how that feels, but I wonder if it‚Äôs claustrophobic?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>I have vivid mem­o­ries of the fer­ment of the late 2000s, a new social net­work flar­ing up every week! I lived in San Francisco; they were build­ing them in offices around a narrow, scrag­gly park. That fun froth hard­ened into a com­pact drama­tis per­sonae that has remained basi­cally unchanged for years now. So, here comes <span class="nobr">Web3 — </span><wbr>and the basic emo­tional appeal of NEW OPTIONS can­not be overstated.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Many Web3 boost­ers see them­selves as disruptors, but ‚Äútokenize all the things‚Äù is noth­ing if not an obe­di­ent con­tin­u­a­tion of ‚Äúmarket-ize all the things‚Äù, <a href="https://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php?isbn=9780674064362">the cam­paign started in the 1970s</a>, hugely suc­cessful, ongoing. In a way, the World Wide Web was the <span class="nobr">rupture — </span><wbr>‚ÄúWhere … is the money?‚Äù‚Äîwhich Web¬†2.0 smoothed over and Web3 now attempts to seal totally.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A large frac­tion of Web3‚Äôs mag­net­ism comes from the value of the under­ly­ing cryptocurrencies. Therefore, a good diag­nos­tic ques­tion to ask might be: would you still be curi­ous about Web3 if those cur­ren­cies were worthless, in dol­lar terms? For some peo­ple, the answer is ‚Äúyes, absolutely‚Äù, because they find the foun­da­tional puz­zles so compelling. For others, if they‚Äôre honest, the answer is ‚Äúnnnot reallyyy‚Äù.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>I didn‚Äôt pro­duce my NFT project in 2019 or 2020; I pro­duced it in early 2021, when a wave of hype, whipped up by tales of windfalls, came crash­ing across my screen. That‚Äôs me being honest!</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>‚ÄúI am brainless, but money is the real brain of all things, and how then should its pos­ses­sor be brainless? Besides, he can buy clever peo­ple for himself, and is he who has power over the clever not more clever than the clever? Do not I, who, thanks to money, am capa­ble of all that the human heart longs for, pos­sess all human capacities? Does not my money, therefore, trans­form all my inca­pac­i­ties into their contrary?‚Äù</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The money thing con­founds evaluation; it‚Äôs like try­ing to look at a star next to the sun. The same was true for the World Wide Web in the year 2000, of course; and, if that‚Äôs the analogy, what do we make of it?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The term Web3 plays on ‚ÄúWeb¬†2.0‚Äù, pop­u­lar­ized in the 2000s to describe a new gen­er­a­tion of web­sites and web platforms. As a philosophy, Web¬†2.0‚Äôs suc­cess was incomplete, to say the least: there was a whole thick strand of ambi­tion around the exchange of data in modular, per­mis­sive ways between plat­forms, which basi­cally <span class="nobr">died — </span><wbr>or was killed. With that in mind, I think Web3 is a fine term for this new set of ideas, because it will cer­tainly play out the same way: influ­enc­ing the direc­tion of the inter­net, but incompletely; unpredictably.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Even at com­pa­ra­ble stages in their development, the World Wide Web and Web¬†2.0 were not quite so … self-referential? They were about other <span class="nobr">things — </span><wbr>sci­ence and cof­fee pots, links and cam­era <span class="nobr">lenses — </span><wbr>while Web3 is, to a first approximation, about Web3.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Web3 is best under­stood as a game, or a game of games. I don‚Äôt intend that as a dig: it‚Äôs a really good game! Vast and open-ended, deeply social, with lots of scores to tally … AND you can win real money?? I mean, that‚Äôs terrific.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Web3 promises <span class="nobr">rewards — </span><wbr>maybe even a kind of <span class="nobr">justice — </span><wbr>for ‚Äúusers‚Äù, but Ethereum doesn‚Äôt know anything about users, only wallets. One user can control many wallets; one <em>bot</em> can con­trol many wallets; Ethereum can‚Äôt tell the difference, doesn‚Äôt par­tic­u­larly care. Therefore, Web3‚Äôs gov­er­nance tools are appro­pri­ate for decision-making processes that approx­i­mate those of an LLC, but not for anything truly democratic, which is to say, any­thing that respects the uniform, <span class="nobr">unearned — </span><wbr><span class="nobr">unearned! — </span><wbr>value of per­son­hood.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The somewhat-ridiculed cryp­tocur­rency <a href="https://worldcoin.org/">Worldcoin</a>, with its retina-scanning orb, is one attempt to solve this problem. <a href="https://www.brightid.org/">There are others.</a> They tie them­selves into knots try­ing to arrive at per­son­hood in a uni­verse of wallets.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A UNI­VERSE OF WALLETS.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>I have a hunch there is some equiv­a­lent to G√∂del‚Äôs incom­plete­ness the­o­rem wait­ing in the wings for Web3 governance. Remember: The <span class="nobr">DAO — </span><wbr>first of its kind, from which all present DAOs take their <span class="nobr">name — </span><wbr>failed so badly it required <em>a fork of the Ethereum blockchain</em>. The buzzy <a href="https://www.fwb.help/">Friends With Benefits</a> ‚Äúsocial token‚Äù was hacked, and its recon­sti­tu­tion was man­aged not with the mech­a­nisms of Web3 gov­er­nance, but ‚Äúout-of-band‚Äù, on Twit­ter, Medium, and Discord. This is going to keep happening!</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Does a ‚ÄúWeb3‚Äù that depends on Twitter for its mar­ket­ing and coor­di­na­tion chan­nel really deserve the name? You might say, ‚ÄúOh, just wait; Web3 will make a Twit­ter of its own.‚Äù No, it won‚Äôt. Such a plat­form would be use­less to Web3, because there would be no one there to recruit üòà</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>I feel like this sim­ple premise is often lost in the haze: the Ethereum Vir­tual Machine, hum­ming heart of Web3, is a com­puter that charges you many dol­lars to exe­cute a very small pro­gram very slowly. It does so in an envi­ron­ment with spe­cial properties, and in some cases, those prop­er­ties are worth the expense. In others … it‚Äôs like run­ning your web­site on a TRS-80 with a coin slot.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A key <span class="nobr">characteristic — </span><wbr>really, a key <em>aesthetic</em>‚Äîof most (all?) blockchains is immutability. They are ledgers, after all. But, these days, where the inter­net is concerned, I find myself more inter­ested in the opposite; in muta­bil­ity and ephemerality. I like things that can change and grow, then vanish.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>I am a BIG fan of deletion, an oper­a­tion basi­cally anti­thet­i­cal to Web3.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What do we lose when we lose deletion?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>At this point, Ethereum is here to stay (for a decade, at least), which means the same is prob­a­bly true for Web3. I would like to see it fire­walled into the realm of finance and the finance-adjacent: speculation games.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>I‚Äôll close with credit where due: Ethereum should inspire any­one inter­ested in the future(s) of the inter­net, because it proves, pow­er­fully, that new pro­to­cols are still pos­si­ble. I do not think Web3 is a desir­able or even tol­er­a­ble path for­ward for this web right here, but I take its les­son well. ‚ÄúCode wins arguments‚Äù, and so do clubs, and cults; time remains to build all three.</p>
<p class="spacetime">November 2021</p>
